pull.title: wallet: fix BnB selection upper bound
pull.body:
As BnB is an algorithm specialized in seeking changeless solutions, the
final selection amount (the sum of all the selected UTXOs amount) can be
as high as one unit below the target + what would have been the cost for
creating and spending the change output.
In other words, the target plus what the transaction creation process
expects to waste with the creation of the change output.

Which means that the range of the possible solutions is:
target <= solution_amount < target + cost_of_change - 1.

Note:
This should solve the issue presented in #28372.

----------------------------------------------

Pending TO DO for this week:

Think more about the previous `min_viable_change` changes (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/1167ab95e0c07392eec678cd0f19e2c4189c5abe).

As we are using the minimum viable change amount to calculate change (we provide it to `GetChange()`).
We might also be having a non-changeless solution in BnB for the following scenario:

When BnB_solution_amount - target >= target + min_viable_change and BnB_solution_amount - target < target + cost_of_change.

In other words, when the excess is in-between `min_viable_change` and `cost_of_change`. This ofc relies on
`cost_of_change` being strictly greater than `min_viable_change`.

issue.title: fuzz: improve `coinselection`
issue.body:
This PR:

- Moves coin creation to its own function called `CreateCoins`.
- Add coverage for `EligibleForSpending`
- Add coverage for `AddInputs`: get result of each algorithm (srd, knapsack and bnb), call `CreateCoins` and add into them.
- Add coverage for `GetShuffledInputVector` and `GetInputSet` using the result of each algorithm (srd, knapsack and bnb).
- Add coverage for `Merge`: Call SRD with the new utxos and, if successful, try to merge with the previous SRD result.

issue.title: Fix waste calculation in SelectionResult
issue.body:
PR #26152 moved waste calculation into SelectionResult to be able to correct the waste score on basis of the bump_fee_group_discount for overlapping ancestries. This left two functions with largely overlapping purpose, where one was simply a wrapper of the other. This PR cleans up the overlap, and fixes the double-meaning of `change_cost` where the `GetChange()` function assumed that no change was created when `change_cost` was set to 0. This behavior was exploited in a bunch of tests, but is problematic, because a `change_cost` of 0 is permitted with custom settings for feerate and discard_feerate (i.e. when they’re both 0).

Requires #26152, only last two commits are new.

--
It needs to change unit tests and fuzz.

coinselection: bugfix, use min_viable_change on BnB selection upper bound

As BnB is an algorithm specialized in seeking changeless solutions, the
final selection amount (the sum of all the selected UTXOs amount) can be
as high as one unit below the amount where the transaction creation
process starts creating a change output. Which is: target + min_viable_change - 1.

In other words, the range of the possible solutions is:
target <= solution_amount < target + min_viable_change - 1.

verification.payload:
tree 40bae7361dc928d30752e12815651f2a497d545d
parent 1e83af161f29455c2aee5d50f4d8d8ffa4a0cb1b
author furszy <matiasfurszyfer@protonmail.com> 1693755763 -0300
committer furszy <matiasfurszyfer@protonmail.com> 1693756077 -0300

test: coinselection, add coverage for BnB upper bound selection

The following cases are covered:
1) The only available solution contain an excess equal to min_viable_change.
   The expected behavior here is BnB search to fail. Because, if BnB would return a valid solution, the transaction
   creation process would create a change output (which is what we don't expect from a BnB solution).

2) The only available solution contain an excess one unit below the min_viable_change.
   The expected behavior here is BnB search returning a successful solution.

   The expected behavior here is BnB search to fail. Because, if BnB would return a valid solution, the transaction

2) The only available solution contain an excess one unit below the min_viable_change.
   The expected behavior here is BnB search returning a successful solution.
